node.contents: looks like your blocking the ui thread. http://developer.android.com/training/articles/perf-anr.html.

node.contents: I have around 2000 lines of text which I am displaying on the textview wrapped by scrollview. Shall I split it into multiple screens with swipe/next,previous buttons or some better alternative is there?

astNode.text: I have around 2000 lines of text which I am displaying on the textview wrapped by scrollview. Shall I split it into multiple screens with swipe/next,previous buttons or some better alternative is there?

node.contents: yes, this is very probelmatic. there are however many possible solutions. i think the best one for you could be a listView with multiple textView instances. if you are new to listView, watch the google io lecture "the world of listView" : http://www.google.com/events/io/2010/sessions/world-of-listview-android.html

astNode.text: yes, this is very probelmatic. there are however many possible solutions. i think the best one for you could be a listView with multiple textView instances. if you are new to listView, watch the google io lecture "the world of listView" : http://www.google.com/events/io/2010/sessions/world-of-listview-android.html

node.contents: just don't run long (or things that could on some cases be long) operations on the UI thread.

astNode.text: just don't run long (or things that could on some cases be long) operations on the UI thread.

node.contents: this includes: DB operations, internet operations, complex calculations, large storage operations (like writing a large file) , ...

astNode.text: this includes: DB operations, internet operations, complex calculations, large storage operations (like writing a large file) , ...

node.contents: each of those operations can run on asyncTask , a new thread, a service with a thread , an intentService, syncAdapter, thread pool ,...

astNode.text: each of those operations can run on asyncTask , a new thread, a service with a thread , an intentService, syncAdapter, thread pool ,...

node.contents: when the operation are finished, you can use a Handler object to tell the UI everything has finished.

astNode.text: when the operation are finished, you can use a Handler object to tell the UI everything has finished.

node.contents: Generally an ANR occurs if an application cannot respond to user input. The most common case is when you do some heave tasks in the main UI thread. That tasks blocks the work flow and thus creats ANR.

astNode.text: Generally an ANR occurs if an application cannot respond to user input. The most common case is when you do some heave tasks in the main UI thread. That tasks blocks the work flow and thus creats ANR.

node.contents: To resolve this you should use different thread rather than the UI thread to perform the heavy tasks. You canuse different worker thread, AsyncTask or post Runnable to handler to perform the tasks.

astNode.text: To resolve this you should use different thread rather than the UI thread to perform the heavy tasks. You canuse different worker thread, AsyncTask or post Runnable to handler to perform the tasks.

node.contents: To know details about ANR and resolving this check this nice article
